title: Sell property, but save Long Term Capital Gains Tax (Vinod Arora)
text: By Vinod Arora Jul 2, 2015 In the long-term, there is no business like selling property. It gives handsome returns on an almost consistent basis. But selling property is not as easy as it looks. Once you're done with the legal formalities, you also need to consider the tax implications. Stamp duties as well as other property taxes and charges are not all that you have to pay when you sell property - be it your land, house, or some commercial premises. There is also Long Term Capital Gains Tax. Whenever you sell property after holding it for 36 months, you have made Long Term Capital Gains in India, which is how the Income Tax return asks you to identify it.So, how much is the Long Term Capital Gains Tax really? And is there a legal way to avoid it?First, there is a flat 20% tax on your long term capital gains in India . However, if in your computation of the figure, you choose not to go for Indexation, i.e. adjustment for cost inflation index, then you will pay tax at 10%.Second, you can avoid this tax by investing in government bonds in India .How to calculate the Long Term Capital Gains tax?* Note down the final figure of your property transaction* Deduct the expenditure incurred over this transaction - registration, stamp duty, legal costs, brokerage fees etc.* Deduct the expenditure incurred over any improvements or construction you undertook over this property* Deduct the exemptions under various sections of the Income Tax Act* Deduct any losses that you may have incurred in any long-term asset transaction in the same financial year. This loss can be set off in the next eight financial years * This final figure is your Long Term Capital gains in India.How do government bonds in India help in saving the Long Term Capital Gains Tax?For avoiding being taxed on long term capital gains in India, there are two government bonds India for you to consider - National Highways Authority of India and Rural Electrification Corporation. Within six months of your property transfer, if you invest in these two bonds, you can claim exemption under section 54 EC.You can claim an exemption on your investment or the capital gains, whichever is lower.There is a rider though. In a financial year, you can invest a maximum of Rs. 50 lakh, both bonds taken together. Currently, this investment will get you returns at an interest rate of 6%. There is a lock-in period of 3 years on investment in these bonds.So, make money on your property sale, invest the gains, and make some more money.
